p.s: Shakespeare himself probably never even met somebody Jewish throughout his life.
Still he believes himself in a position to write a play in which a Jew is representing the villain who is hated by nearly every other character.
Did this raise awareness for the problem of antisemitism in the Elizabethan era?
Probably not, btu might do justice today.

In the following I will discuss whether The Merchant of Venice 1596/97 by William Shakespeare, a renowned playwright at this time and further on, fuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes or raises awareness for the problem of antisemitism.
In my opinion Shylock is a problematic role in this comedy.
He is often referred to as the Jew, sometimes even combined with insulting adjectives.
Moreover, he loosesloses everything throughout the play and in the end he does not even get his money back, nor revenge towards Antonio and even he has to convert to Christianity.
At the end of the play he is standing there alone, without anybody else but the people in Venice disrepting him and spitting on him.
Still their play is considered a comedy even though comedies are known for their happy endings.
So if this is supposed to be a happy ending, how ca we say that this play raises awareness for the problem of antisemitism?
It seems to be doing the opposite.
In the Elizabethan era adherents of a different religion than Christianity were persecuted.
Therefore prejudices played a major role during this time.
It is ahrd to argue that Shakespeare was trying to raise awarnessawareness even though he included Shylock's famous speech about Jews not being different from other people.
But we do not know how audiences reacted to this speech.
Whether they took it serious or whether they were blind by their societal standards and fears.
Therefore this play appears to have fueled antisemeticanti-semeticstereotypes during Elizabeth's reign.
Nowadays we are able to look at this play from a different perspective.
We are able to express our opinion freely and reflect on prejudices and stereotypes.
We are able to see flaws in old literature, stereotypes that can be overcome.
But in my opinion we do not have to censor literature for that.
Forbidding a play will make it even more interesting and meaningful to people who misuse it.
We should rather learn from the play and the historical facts that it conveys.

To conclude I will say that The Merchant of Venice might have fueled antisemitism in the Elizabethan era but can be considered as a play that raises awareness for the problem of antisemitism nowadays.
We can learn from history and we most definitely should.
